content: The Act titled "Student Loan Fairness Consolidation Act of 2003" allows for the refinancing of existing consolidation loans. The Student Loan Fairness Consolidation Act of 2003 allows borrowers to refinance existing consolidation loans at a variable interest rate, excluding loans used to repay Federal Direct PLUS Loans or loans made under section 428B. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 provide for refinancing options for FFEL Consolidation Loans and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans, including variable interest rate consolidation loans with specific rate calculations. The Student Loan Fairness Consolidation Act of 2003 allows borrowers to refinance existing consolidation loans at a variable interest rate. If the applicable interest rate for a consolidation loan exceeds the special allowance rate, an adjustment is made by calculating and crediting the excess interest to the Government based on the loan balance. The Student Loan Fairness Consolidation Act of 2003 allows borrowers to refinance consolidation loans at a variable interest rate, excluding loans used to repay PLUS loans. The Act also specifies that for Federal Direct Consolidation Loans disbursed after a certain date, the interest rate will vary annually from July 1 to June 30. The Student Loan Fairness Consolidation Act of 2003 allows borrowers to refinance consolidation loans at a variable interest rate determined annually based on the bond equivalent rate of 91-day Treasury bills plus 2.3%, capped at 8.25%. This provision does not apply to consolidation loans used solely to repay section 428B loans or Federal Direct PLUS Loans. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to section 438(b)(2)(I) by including section 427A(m) in the list of applicable sections.
